column1: Millcreek is a city in Salt Lake County
column4: and is part of the Salt Lake City Metropolitan Statistical Area. Prior to its incorporation on December 28
column6: Millcreek was a census-designated place (CDP) and township.

column1: The first settlers of the Millcreek area in 1848 included Mary Fielding Smith (widow of Hyrum Smith) and her children
column2: including Joseph F. Smith. The area remained essentially rural in character until after World War II. As postwar suburban growth spilled south over the Salt Lake City limits
column3: the area was not annexed by the city and remained unincorporated.

column2: most of the area now in Millcreek was built out and known by various names
column4: Canyon Rim and Mount Olympus. In the 2000 census
column5: the area was divided among four CDPs
column6: the westernmost of which was designated Millcreek CDP. The population of this CDP was 30
column8: and had a total area of 4.9 square miles (12.8 km²). Canyon Rim CDP
column10: and Mount Olympus CDP were consolidated with Millcreek CDP in the 2010 census
column12: 139.Salt Lake County created Millcreek Township in 2002 as an administrative subentity that included the populated CDPs as well as undeveloped Mill Creek Canyon in the Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest immediately to the east. The township was created to give residents of the area more local control over planning and prevent annexations by neighboring cities.

column1: As other communities south of Salt Lake City were incorporated in the 1990s and 2000s
column2: Millcreek remained as the most populous unincorporated area of Salt Lake County. Residents considered a number of options for their future
column4: which would make it the county's fifth-largest city. Amalgamation with neighboring South Salt Lake was also proposed
column5: which would have combined South Salt Lake's commercial and industrial base with Millcreek’s heavily residential character
column7: 000.The incorporation of Millcreek was the subject of a contentious 2012 ballot question
column8: which set the boundaries of the proposed city identical to that of Millcreek Township
column9: and asked voters what form of municipal government should be implemented. The initiative failed with only 40 percent of the vote
column10: leaving Millcreek under the jurisdiction of the Salt Lake County Mayor and Council
column11: as are other unincorporated areas of the county.

column1: Despite the failure of the initiative in 2012
column2: the question was put on the ballot again three years later
column3: and Millcreek residents voted for incorporation on November 3
column5: residents voted for a mayor and city council members in advance of incorporation
column6: which was recorded at 9:30 a.m. on December 28

column2: Millcreek is wedged between Salt Lake City and South Salt Lake on the north and Murray and Holladay on the south. Millcreek residents typically identify with Salt Lake City
column3: which is designated by the U.S. Postal Service as the “default” place name for mailing addresses in the area. However
column4: “Millcreek” is a recognized place name for addresses in the ZIP codes 84106
column8: and 84124. The city is organized into four community councils
column13: roughly corresponding to the former CDPs.

column1: This climatic region is typified by large seasonal temperature differences
column2: with warm to hot summers and cold (sometimes severely cold) winters.  According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column3: Millcreek has a humid continental climate
